Now, translating the first Java program into Fortran:

First, the first part:

Read N, L, R, QL, QR, then N integers into an array W.

Compute the sum array. The sum array in Java is sum[0] = 0, sum[1] = W[0], sum[2] = W[0]+W[1], etc. So in Fortran, we can have an array sum of size N+1, with sum(1) = 0, and then loop from 1 to N, sum(n+1) = sum(n) + W(n).
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: Wait, in Java, the loop is for n from 0 to N-1 (since W has N elements). So in Fortran, the indices would be 1-based. So in Fortran, the W array would be of size N, with indices 1 to N. The sum array would be size N+1, with sum(1) = 0, and for each i from 1 to N, sum(i+1) = sum(i) + W(i).
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: Then, the loop over firstR from 0 to N (inclusive).
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: In Java, firstR is from 0 to N. For each firstR, lCount is firstR (since firstR is the number of elements on the left?), then rCount is N - lCount. Then compute the candidate value as sum[lCount] * L + (sum[N] - sum[lCount])
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: * R. Then compute llCount and rrCount as max(0, lCount - rCount -1) and max(0, rCount - lCount -1). Then add llCount * QL and rrCount * QR to the candidate. Keep track of the minimum.
children.label: code_analysis

after reading N.

Let's see:

We can declare sum as an array of size N+1, with indices 1 to N+1. Wait, but in Java, sum[0] is 0, sum[1] = W[0], etc. So in Fortran, perhaps:

integer, dimension(0:N) :: sum

But in Fortran, arrays are declared with explicit sizes. So perhaps:

allocate(sum(0:N))
children.label: language_mapping

children.text:
So:

program main

implicit none

integer :: N, L, R, QL, QR

integer, allocatable :: W(:), sum(:)

integer*8 :: min_val, cand

integer :: firstR, lCount, rCount, llCount, rrCount

character(len=20) :: str_min

! Read inputs

read*, N, L, R, QL, QR

allocate(W(N), sum(0:N))

read*, (W(i), i=1,N)

! Compute sum array

sum(0) = 0

do i = 1, N

   sum(i) = sum(i-1) + W(i)

end do

! Initialize min_val to a large value

min_val = huge(min_val) do firstR = 0, N

   lCount = firstR

   rCount = N - lCount

   cand = sum(lCount) * L + (sum(N) - sum(lCount)) * R

   llCount = max(0, lCount - rCount -1)

   rrCount = max(0, rCount - lCount -1)

   cand = cand + llCount * QL + rrCount * QR

   if (cand < min_val) then

      min_val = cand

   end if

end do

!
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Now, process the second part

!

program main

implicit none

integer :: N, L, R, QL, QR

integer, allocatable :: W(:), sum(:)

integer*8 :: min_val, cand

integer :: firstR, lCount, rCount, llCount, rrCount, i

character(len=20) :: str_min

logical :: hasA, hasB

! Read inputs

read*, N, L, R, QL, QR

allocate(W(N), sum(0:N))

read*, (W(i), i=1,N)

! Compute sum array

sum(0) = 0

do i = 1, N

   sum(i) = sum(i-1) + W(i)

end do

! Initialize min_val to a large value

min_val = huge(min_val) do firstR = 0, N

   lCount = firstR

   rCount = N - lCount

   cand = sum(lCount) * L + (sum(N) - sum(lCount)) * R

   llCount = max(0, lCount - rCount -1)

   rrCount = max(0, rCount - lCount -1)

   cand = cand + llCount * QL + rrCount * QR

   if (cand < min_val) then

      min_val = cand

   end if

end do

!

Then, the sum array:

allocate(sum(0:N)) or declare as sum(0:N). Wait, in Fortran arrays are 1-based by default, but can be declared with lower bounds. Let's see:

We can declare sum as an array of size N+1, with indices 1 to N+1. Wait, but in Java, sum[0] is 0, sum[1] = W[0], etc. So in Fortran, perhaps:

So:

program main

implicit none

integer :: N, L, R, QL, QR

integer, allocatable :: W(:), sum(:)

integer*8 :: min_val, cand

integer :: firstR, lCount, rCount, llCount, rrCount

character(len=20) :: str_min

! Read inputs

read*, N, L, R, QL, QR

allocate(W(N), sum(0:N))

read*, (W(i), i=1,N)

! Compute sum array

sum(0) = 0

do i = 1, N

   sum(i) = sum(i-1) + W(i)

end do

! Initialize min_val to a large value

min_val = huge(min_val)

do firstR = 0, N

   lCount = firstR

   rCount = N - lCount

   cand = sum(lCount) * L + (sum(N) - sum(lCount)) * R

   llCount = max(0, lCount - rCount -1)

   rrCount = max(0, rCount - lCount -1)

   cand = cand + llCount * QL + rrCount * QR

   if (cand < min_val) then

      min_val = cand

   end if

end do

! Now, process the second part

! Convert min_val to string

write(str_min, '(I0)') min_val

! Check if the string contains both 'A' and 'B'

logical :: hasA, hasB

hasA = .false.

hasB = .false.

do i = 1, len_trim(str_min)

   if (str_min(i:i) == 'A') then

      hasA = .true.

   else if (str_min(i:i) == 'B') then

      hasB = .true.

   end if

end do

if (hasA .and. hasB) then

   print*, 'Yes'

else

   print*, 'No'

end if

deallocate(W, sum)

end program

program main

implicit none

integer :: N, L, R, QL, QR

integer, allocatable :: W(:), sum(:)

integer*8 :: min_val, cand

integer :: firstR, lCount, rCount, llCount, rrCount, i

character(len=20) :: str_min

logical :: hasA, hasB

! Read inputs

read*, N, L, R, QL, QR

allocate(W(N), sum(0:N))

read*, (W(i), i=1,N)

! Compute sum array

sum(0) = 0

do i = 1, N

   sum(i) = sum(i-1) + W(i)

end do

! Initialize min_val to a large value

min_val = huge(min_val)

do firstR = 0, N

   lCount = firstR

   rCount = N - lCount

   cand = sum(lCount) * L + (sum(N) - sum(lCount)) * R

   llCount = max(0, lCount - rCount -1)

   rrCount = max(0, rCount - lCount -1)

   cand = cand + llCount * QL + rrCount * QR

   if (cand < min_val) then

      min_val = cand

   end if

end do

! Convert min_val to string

write(str_min, '(I0)') min_val

! Check for 'A' and 'B'

hasA = .false.

hasB = .false.

do i = 1, len_trim(str_min)

   if (str_min(i:i) == 'A') then

      hasA = .true.

   else if (str_min(i:i) == 'B') then

      hasB = .true.

   end if

end do

if (hasA .and. hasB) then

   print*, 'Yes'

else

   print*, 'No'

end if

deallocate(W, sum)

end program
